reviewText: Martha Argerich, Evgeny Kissin, Emmanuel Ax, Leif Ove Andsnes, Mikhail Pletnev, Claude Frank, Staffan Scheja, Lang Lang and James Levine: pianists.The 'Happy Birthday' string orchestra: Gidon Kremer, Vadim Repin, Renaud Capuon, Sarah Chang, Ilya Gringolts, Yuri Bashmet, Nobuko Imai, Christian Tetzlaff, Nikolaj Znaider, Dmitry Sitkovetsky, Mischa Maisky, Boris Pergamenschikow, Patrick de los Santos.Such a tremendous cast represents the gathering of the best contemproary classical musicians!It is more than just fun, though fun it certainly was. This DVD is an outstanding documentary of a big musical event.I don't see any artist really 'dominating' the scene - Levine, being a conductor cum pianist, certainly wasn't imposing 'his' will on other soloists; nor did any senior musician seen to patronise younger ones (the youngest being Vadim Repin and Sarah Chung, violinists, and Kissin and Lang Lang, pianisits).No - everybody were enjoying the get together on a purely equal basis. And it is this great fraternity that brings out the true dignity of music as an art form.Classical music deserves to live; not to die.
Title: N/A

reviewText: At first I hesitated for the obvious lack of Glenn Gould's capacity for polyphonic music: how would one be able to tell head from tail when so many pianos are playing at the same time?Relax, and put your heart at ease, and do what the musicians here are doing and enjoy. These are no ordinary musicians but top musicians and they are having a marvelous time and they are sharing with you their joy. Martha Argerich and Kissin are doing a four hands piece as an overture and then, pieces for two pianos and more and more pianos, with the wonderful string players like Kremer and Maisky and even some singers in between. Basically it was Kissin stringing the whole concert together. The concert was such a success and it's  thoroughly enjoyable with lots of fun.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The DVD starts maybe a touch slow but boy are you in for a ride after a while! This is such an enjoyable DVD, particularly the end with eight pianists playing sublimely in synchronism it blows your mind. What a fantastic way to show how much fun the piano can be!
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, I have to confess to a mistake.  For most of my life, I have steadfastly maintained that music is to be heard, not watched.Well, that position may be Logical, but it is not necessarily True.Consider this amazing DVD.  The first part stars Martha Argerich and Evgeny Kissin playing a wonderful piano "duet" by Mozart.  It is truly fascinating to watch the interactions between the older woman and the younger guy, as they perform flawless music!Then another piano is wheeled onto the stage, and four master pianists whomp it up with a piece by Smetana.  After a "Happy Birthday" piece, we are treated to J.S. Bach's "Concerto for Four Pianos and Orchestra in a Minor."I could stop right here, and so I guess I should.  The world's greatest pianists, playing some of the best piano music ever written: well, it's just fabulous!!!In case you haven't guessed, I love this DVD!!  :-)
summary: Absolutely one of the best DVDs I own
Title: N/A

reviewText: This belongs in all piano and string collectors' libraries.  It is the sort of item one will certainly return to  and share with music-loving friends.The Verbier Festival, in a truly beautiful Swiss village (are there Alpine Swiss villages that are not beautiful?) is one of the lesser known but most prestigious summer festivals in Europe.... it simply attracts the best of the best to teach and guide the students who attend the Festival Academy.Without detracting in any way from the feat of Martin T:Son Engström, Verbier's founder, something which should be acknowledged  repeatedly, is the tremendous debt of gratitude we music lovers owe Martha Argerich and Gidon Kremer.  Their ability to bring together, not only in Verbier, but in various other venues as well, the, arguably, "best and the brightest" of musicians to play together for the sheer joy of music-making is unparalleled in my lifetime.  Perhaps Marlboro, in the days of Rudolf Serkin and Casals was an approximation, but not to the degree that Kremer and Argerich, together and independently of each other have achieved. The artistry and happiness their chamber music playing bring can be enjoyed in many live recordings that have stemmed from these gatherings (e.g. the Argerich Schumann celebration and Kremer's various Lockenhaus outings). These are musicians coming together to celebrate the art of music: their joy is infectious.As to the DVD: it records the Festival's 10th anniversary which coincided with it's founder's 50th birthday.  No solo playing is offered but there is music for piano four hands, 2-pianos 8 hands, 4 pianos and string orchestra, and, astonishingly, eight pianos. Imagine the array of pianists: Martha Argerich, Evgeny Kissin, Emmanuel Ax, Leif Ove Andsnes, Mikhail Pletnev, Claude Frank, Staffan Scheja, Lang Lang and Jimmy Levine.  Imagine the string orchestra: Gidon Kremer, Vadim Repin, Renaud Capuon, Sarah Chang, Ilya Gringolts, Yuri Bashmet, Nobuko Imai, Christian Tetzlaff, Nikolaj Znaider, Dmitry Sitkovetsky, Mischa Maisky, Boris Pergamenschikow, Patrick de los Santos. In my lifetime I do not recall so much soloist talent gathering to play with each other in any one stage..... not even the Carnegie Hall "Concert of the Century."And the music! From the sublime to the bombastic, one draws energy from witnessing the rapport, dedication, and, again, joy, these masters bring to playing together, and of course the musical results they achieve.  In purely musical terms, highest points for me were the  Mozart Sonata for piano, four hands, K.521, (Argerich and Kissin), and the Bach concerto for four pianos, particularly the ecstatic second movement (Pletnev, Levine, Kissin and Argerich). Everything is at least interesting and never less than fun..... when the eight pianos come together I particularly enjoyed the Rossini Semiramide Overture and the Flight of the Bumble Bee.Get this.  I assure you you will enjoy it many times over. And our thanks to all these wonderful musicians and to Mr. Engström for making it all happen.... and to BMG for producing such a fine DVD.... the DTS is great.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The description of the DVD/program is already said and the artists introduced, so I'll just say that this DVD rocks!Each performance is top rate, as you have top rate artists, and their joy and excitement is simply infectious.  These artists make you really really really want to learn how to make music.  How wonderful music is!  The artists are from all over the world.  Leaving behind all the differences they might have, they put their souls and artistry together and become one huge inspiring fire ball.  It is absolutely enchanting.  The Happy B-day variations are a real treat. Sarah Chang's beautiful huge ear-to-ear smiles were contageous and music by itself; they will snap you out of depression.  If you're depressed, go get a copy of this DVD. It is much more effective than going to a doctor or taking anti-depressant.The 8 pianos are amazing as well.  Of course, there are moments that they aren't quite in perfect sync, but their sheer joy overrides those moments, and you become their captive.  It is simply fun to watch/listen.  Also, you will see how differently each pianist plays.  It is a very good study for young pianists, as these pianists are all top-rated artists.  I watched it over and over again, especially right before my students' recital.  In fact, I am planning on giving it to one of my students for her B-day that's coming up this summer.Behind all this fun and smiles, you never know what kind of hard life these artists had to endure when they were growing up learning and competing, to get to this level.  They deserve all the fun in the world!  And really, music is for us to enjoy and appreciate.My only complaint is the "behind the scene" section.  I think it was Lavine who was talking when the interview ends abruptly sort of, and the "behind the scene" ends without a solid conclusion.  You sort of feel an "unfinished" kind of dissatisfaction there. But I still appreciate their effort to have this section filmed.I recommend this DVD for anybody who loves music, especially for students who are under pressure and beginning to feel that they want to "quit".  Don't quit!!!  Just watch this DVD.  You will regain strength to keep going.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I bought this dvd in 12/06 and thought back then the DTS track was the best recorded music I had heard so far in my life.The sound stage is 150 degrees wide, the applause is from the sides and it trully gives you the impression of being there. The pieces with 8 pianos placed in the form of an isosceles trapezoid let you hear every single piano in it's virtual spot in front of you. Just outstandingly recorded. There are half a dozen people credited for the sound.Even today I use this dvd probably as the 3rd to showcase the sound in my music room, right after Mahlers 9th with the Mahler Youth Orchestra (which is in a class by itself) and the blu ray The Barber of Seville with Florez/Bayo by the Madrid Opera.What a bargain.
summary: Even in 2011 still one of the best DTS sound tracks
Title: N/A

reviewText: What's wrong with pianists having fun? I own a copy of this dvd, and I have to say it's a thrill to see pianists playing with so much JOY and so obviously enjoying themselves. Piano playing doesn't have to be dry, grim, and determined all the time. There are Beethoven sonatas for that. The performances are top rate--how can it be otherwise, with Martha Argerich, Kissin, Levine, Ax, and other name-droppables on the line. Plus, the Happy Birthday variations ROCK! A must-have for all piano enthusiasts.
Title: N/A
